title: Sarah Jessica Parker admits to being freaked out by selfie-seeking fans grabbing her
text:
Sarah Jessica Parker looked particularly uncomfortable this week when Australian fans flocked to get a closer look and pictures with the American actress.

And now the Sex And The City Star, 54, has revealed that overzealous admirers often scare or freak her out.

While Sarah loves her fans' enthusiasm, she told the Herald Sun on Tuesday that she wished they'd consider her personal boundaries more.

'People grabbing me freaks me out!' Sarah Jessica Parker has admitted that it's scary and unacceptable when selfie-seeking fans touch her without asking for permission first

Sarah, who is in Australia to promote her the launch of her SJP shoe collection in David Jones, said some selfie-seeking fans make her feel afraid.

'The world is scary a little bit right now, there’s a heightened awareness, there’s tension, so that’s the only thing that freaks me out is people grabbing me. I much prefer conversation to a selfie,' she explained.

Sarah added: 'What’s happening now is that people actually grab you, people want a selfie, so there’s no exchange of, "Hello, how are you? Do you mind for a moment if we do a photograph?" It’s "Can we do a selfie?"'

'There’s no introduction and when they’re doing it they’re grabbing you,' Sarah clarified further.

Short visit: Sarah, who is in Australia to promote her the launch of her SJP shoe collection in David Jones, said some selfie-seeking fans make her feel afraid

'There’s no introduction and when they’re doing it they’re grabbing you': Sarah said she'd prefer a conversation with fans before an abrupt attempt to take a selfie with her

Sarah Jessica is not the first celebrity to call out 'selfie culture' either.

In 2015, Justin Beiber said on his Snapchat: 'The way that you [fans] ask or approach me when you want a photo with me is going to determine if I take a photo or not.'

'I want to enjoy the moment just as you're enjoying the moment, but I can't enjoy it if I'm not feeling like there's any respect given to me at that moment... please just respect me and just treat me the way you would want to be treated,' he added.

In 2016, he then berated a Melbourne fan for persisting in her attempts to get a selfie, saying on camera: 'Look at you, you make me sick!'

'Please just respect me!' In 2015, Justin Beiber said on his Snapchat that fans needed to work on their approach for selfies with him (Pictured: 2016)

The same year, American comedian and actress Amy Schumer went further by swearing off ever taking pictures with fans.

She said she was rushed by a man who was over eager to get a photo with her, and refused to acknowledge her polite request to leave her alone.

On Instagram she wrote: 'Yes, legally you are allowed to take a picture of me. But I was asking you to stop and saying no. I will not take picture with people anymore and it's because of this dude.'
description: Sarah Jessica Parker looked particularly uncomfortable this week as Australian fans flocked to get a closer look at the American actress. Now she has revealed why.
authors: Candice Jackson For Daily Mail Australia
